On Aug. 7, 2025:
Subject: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: Communications Involving the Kids Online Safety Act, SCREEN Act, and Foreign NGO Policy Influence
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the DC Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records from January 1, 2022, to the present, including but not limited to:

1.Communications, internal memoranda, policy drafts, meeting notes, or advisories related to:
- a)The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA)
- b)The SCREEN Act
- c)Any U.S. age verification or online child safety policy proposals.

2.Communications or documents involving the following organizations:
- a)National Center on Sexual Exploitation (NCOSE)
- b)Collective Shout
- c)CEASE (Centre to End All Sexual Exploitation)
- d)Carnegie UK Trust
- e)Yoti (digital ID software provider)

3.Any communications with or internal responses to foreign regulators (e.g., Ofcom, European Commission) related to:
- a)The Online Safety Act (UK)
- b)The Digital Services Act (DSA) (EU)
- c)Impacts on U.S. tech companies or policymaking.

This request is submitted with reference to the July 25, 2025 Interim Staff Report of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee titled:
“The Foreign Censorship Threat: How the European Union’s Digital Services Act Compels Global Censorship and Infringes on American Free Speech.”

This report documents concerns that foreign laws are being used to impose domestic censorship goals through indirect means. This FOIA request seeks to determine whether similar tactics were employed by the aforementioned NGOs or agencies.

I request a waiver of fees as this is in the public interest. I am submitting this on behalf of Alathea LLC.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 15 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Demosthenes Alathea

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Merced County Sheriff's Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Merced County Sheriff's Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

title: Calendar Entries, Iliana Vargas

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Calendar Entries, Iliana Vargas
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to show the following:

1. Calendar entries for Iliana Vargas from October 1, 2025 - November 30, 2025. Please search whatever relevant calendar management tool she uses whether it is Outlook, Google Calendars, iCal, paper calendars or any other format.

2. All agendas for meetings Iliana Vargas attended from December 1, 2025 - December 31, 2025. 

This request is made on behalf of The FOIA Bakery. Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2199580/ 
 
Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2199580/ RESPONSE: Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Please note that certain private information was redacted pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7. Specifically, section 7(1)(b) which exempts certain private information as defined by section 2(c-5) and section 7(1)(c) which exempts personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subject of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. Section 7(1)(f) exempts from release “Preliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records in which opinions are expressed, or policies or actions are formulated, except that a specific record or relevant portion of a record shall not be exempt when the record is publicly cited and identified by the head of the public body.” [5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(f)]. 
You have a right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: Leah Bartelt; Public Access Counselor Office of the Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield, Illinois 62706 E-mail: public.access@ilag.gov 877-299-3642 You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court. 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. Sincerely, Patricia Majchrowicz Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

title: book audit list

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: book audit list
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Public reports show that this school district has been subject to book and curriculum challenges: 

https://www.tnonline.com/20240814/lasd-member-wants-book-audit/ 

https://buckscountybeacon.com/2024/09/moms-for-liberty-lehighton-area-school-district-board-member-wants-to-restrict-access-to-lgbtq-books/ 

Therefore, I request the following: 

1) All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slides formats), and other guidance related to “audit list”, “book audit” and “committee”; “parental consent”, “opt-in”, "follett", "destiny", “fox rothschild”, “solicitor”, or “ellen hopkins”. This includes A) any notes taken during meetings that book and curriculum challenges B) any other document that has been used to help explain book and curriculum challenges, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

2) Any digital communications (including but not limited to emails and text messages) as well as documents, (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) about, pertaining to, or mentioning “sexually explicit”, “gone girl”, “innocence”, "follett", "destiny", “white privilege”, “transgender”, “moms for liberty”, “m4l”, “jack corby”, “sean gleaves”, “pulled books”, “ellen hopkins”, “beyond magenta”, “side by side: having a gay or lesbian sibling”, or “grooming”. 

3) Any emails, presentations, videos, memos, recordings, or other records mentioning “sexually explicit”, “innocence”, “white privilege”, “transgender”, "follett", "destiny", “moms for liberty”, “m4l”, “jack corby”, “sean gleaves”, “pulled books”, or “grooming”. 

Please perform this search for records between July 1, 2024 and the time this request is processed. This request is not for commercial purposes and will be used in the course of reporting for 404 Media, an independent, journalist-owned news site (www.404media.co).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Claire Woodcock

communications.subject: Lehighton Area School District
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

We are in receipt of the Right-to-Know request requesting materials and
documents regarding book auditing, etc. We will be happy to provide you all
of the materials requested to the best of our abilities with only the
necessary redactions that may be required under FERPA and
HIPPA regulations. However, as this is a bit of a major undertaking, we
will need the 30-day extension provided by Pennsylvania law.
-- 
Sincerely,

Jason Moser

Lehighton Area School District

communications.subject: Acknowledgment of FOIA Request 2026-00103 and Reminder of Backlog
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon Requester.

Thank you for your reply. This correspondence confirms the receipt of your FOIA request, seeking all current Standard Operating Procedures maintained by the agency related to FOIA Intake, FOIA Processing, and FOIA Appeals.

Due to the significant backlog caused by the federal shutdown, the FTC is processing requests as quickly as possible but has not yet begun to process yours. As soon as we are able, an individual FTC employee will reach out to let you know that they are starting work on your request and will provide their contact information.

In the meantime, if you have questions or concerns, please reach out to us at foia@ftc.gov<mailto:foia@ftc.gov>. You may also check the status of your FOIA request by visiting http://www.ftc.gov/about-ftc/foia/foia-reading-rooms/track-your-foia-request. This report is updated at the end of each month. If you should have any questions regarding your request, please contact us at foia@ftc.gov<mailto:foia@ftc.gov>. In any call or future correspondence concerning the request, please refer to the following case number FOIA- 2026-00103.
Best,

The FOIA Unit

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2199579/ 
 
Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

Miriam Bhimani 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2199579/ 
RESPONSE: Documents responsive to your request are available to download via the CPS FOIA Center at www.cps.edu/FOIARequests . Please log in with your username and password to access the records. Please note that certain private information was redacted pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/7. Specifically, section 7(1)(b) which exempts certain private information as defined by section 2(c-5) and section 7(1)(c) which exempts personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subject of the information. “Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy” means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subject’s right to privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. Section 7(1)(a) of FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a)) exempts from public release information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing federal or State law and also in accordance with section 7.5(q) of the FOIA (5 ILCS 140/7.5(q)) which exempts from public release information prohibited from being disclosed by the Personnel Records Review Act [820 ILCS 40/0.01 et seq.] Section 7(1)(f) exempts from release “Preliminary drafts, notes, recommendations, memoranda and other records in which opinions are expressed, or policies or actions are formulated, except that a specific record or relevant portion of a record shall not be exempt when the record is publicly cited and identified by the head of the public body.” [5 ILCS 140/7 (1)(f)]. 
You have a right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: Leah Bartelt; Public Access Counselor Office of the Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield, Illinois 62706 E-mail: public.access@ilag.gov 877-299-3642 You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by filing a lawsuit in the State circuit court. 5 ILCS 140/11. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. Sincerely, Patricia Majchrowicz Freedom of Information Act Officer Chicago Public Schools

title: Flock Safety ALPR Audits 2026 Q1 (Aurora Police Department)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Flock Safety ALPR Audits 2026 Q1 (Aurora Police Department)
communications.communication:
RE: Flock Safety ALPR Audits

To the FOIA Officer of Aurora Police Department,

This request is made under the provisions of Illinois Freedom of Information Act. for the following records:

1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

Please provide the audit data in a structured format such as .csv, .xls, or another machine-readable database filetype.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the case of any applicable fees, it is requested that an estimate of the total charges be provided prior to fulfilling this request. The preferred method of receipt is through electronic delivery.

Your assistance and cooperation in this matter are greatly appreciated. A response within 5 business days, as the statute requires is anticipated.

Best,
David S. (he/him/his), Lucy Parsons Labs

To the FOIA Officer of Aurora Police Department, 

This request is made under the provisions of Illinois Freedom of Information Act. for the following records: 

1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency. 

2. Network Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System. 

Please provide the audit data in a structured format such as .csv, .xls, or another machine-readable database filetype. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the case of any applicable fees, it is requested that an estimate of the total charges be provided prior to fulfilling this request. The preferred method of receipt is through electronic delivery. 

Your assistance and cooperation in this matter are greatly appreciated. A response within 5 business days, as the statute requires is anticipated. 

Best, 
David S. (he/him/his), Lucy Parsons Labs 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2206252/ 

Responsive record(s) have been released to our online FOIA Request System. You can log into the system and download your responsive records. Some exempt information has been redacted or withheld, pursuant to the Section 7 provisions of FOIA stated herein. 7(1)(b).  Private information, i.e. personal telephone numbers, home addresses, drivers licenses, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law, or a court order. License plate numbers withheld. 

THIS IS A NOTIFICATION SENT TO YOUR EMAIL ADDRESS VIA GOVQA. YOUR RESPONSIVE RECORDS ARE ATTACHED TO YOUR FOIA REQUEST IN GOVQA. 

You have the right to have this response to your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to: 

Public Access Counselor, Office of the Attorney General 
500 South 2nd Street, Springfield, Illinois 62701 
Phone: 877-299-3642 
E-mail: public.access@ilag.gov 

You also have the right to seek judicial review by filing a lawsuit in the State of Illinois Circuit Court. If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC. 

Sincerely, 
Jill Rangel 
Records Clerk 
Aurora Police Department 
630-256-5720 
This mailbox is not monitored. Please reply directly to the person in your request closure message, not directly to this message. 
 
 
REQUEST FOR PUBLIC RECORDS WILL BE PROCESSED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE  ILLINOIS FOIA. 
All requests for public records will be governed by the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1, and exempt information will be redacted or otherwise withheld.  You may be receiving a redacted version of the requested records.

title: Patel appointment

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Patel appointment
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Introductory announcement, prepared remarks, agenda items, and other materials related to the appointment of Ricky J. Patel as special agent in charge of the New York Area of Responsibility.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Felipe De La Hoz

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-53236
communications.communication:
08/07/2025 
Felipe De  La Hoz 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 190634 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 
RE:        ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-53236 
Dear Requester: 
This acknowledges receipt of your 8/5/2025, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for Introductory announcement, prepared remarks, agenda items, and other materials related to the appointment of Ricky J. Patel as special agent in charge of the New York Area of Responsibility. 

Your request was received in this office on 8/5/2025. 

After careful review of your FOIA request, we determined that your request is not reasonably described due to the reason(s) listed below: 

-Your request is too broad in scop, please narrow. 
-Your request did not specifically identify the records which you are seeking. 
Records must be described in reasonably sufficient detail to enable government employees who are familiar with the subject area to locate records without placing an unreasonable burden upon the agency.  For this reason, §5.3(b) of the DHS regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, require that you describe the records you are seeking with as much information as possible to ensure that our search can locate them with a reasonable amount of effort.  Whenever possible, a request should include specific information about each record sought, such as the date, title or name, author, recipients, case number, and subject matter of the records, if known, or the ICE program office you believe created and/or controls the record. The FOIA does not require an agency to create new records, answer questions posed by requesters, or attempt to interpret a request that does not identify specific records. 

-Clearly identify the subject matter. 
-Provide a date range of X-X days/weeks/months/years. 
-Identify the specific program office, position titles, or individuals. 
-Avoid using general or ambiguous language (e.g. “all communications,” “everything related to,” “all records”). 

If you require assistance to reasonably describe the records you are seeking, please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009. You have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

 

Sincerely, 
ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

communications.subject: ICE FOIA 2025-ICFO-53236
communications.communication:
08/21/2025 

Felipe De  La Hoz 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 190634 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-53236 
 
Dear Requester: 

This acknowledges receipt of your 8/5/2025, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), for Introductory announcement, prepared remarks, agenda items, and other materials related to the appointment of Ricky J. Patel as special agent in charge of the New York Area of Responsibility 

.  Your request was received in this office on 8/5/2025. 

Due to the increasing number of FOIA requests received by this office, we may encounter some delay in processing your request. Per Section 5.5(a) of the DHS FOIA regulations, 6 C.F.R. Part 5, ICE processes FOIA requests according to their order of receipt. Although ICE’s goal is to respond within 20 business days of receipt of your request, the FOIA does permit a 10-day extension of this time period. As your request seeks numerous documents that will necessitate a thorough and wide-ranging search, ICE will invoke a 10-day extension for your request, as allowed by Title 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(B). If you’re able to narrow the scope of your request please contact our office. Narrowing the scope may speed up the search process. We will make every effort to comply with your request in a timely manner. 

Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS Interim FOIA regulations, as they apply to media requesters.  As a media requester, you will be charged 10 cents per page for duplication; the first 100 pages are free.  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00. You will be contacted before any further fees are accrued. 

We have queried the appropriate program offices within ICE for responsive records. If any responsive records are located, they will be reviewed for determination of releasability. Please be assured that one of the processors in our office will respond to your request as expeditiously as possible. We appreciate your patience as we proceed with your request. 

If you have any questions, please contact FOIA Public Liaison, Daniel Edgington at 500 12th Street, SW, Washington DC 20536 or (866) 633-1182. Additionally, you have a right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Your request has been assigned reference number 2025-ICFO-53236. Please use this number in future correspondence. 

Sincerely, 

ICE FOIA Office 
Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Freedom of Information Act Office 
500 12th Street, S.W., Stop 5009 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5009

communications.subject: ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-53236
communications.communication:
Felipe De  La Hoz 
MuckRock News DEPT MR 190634 
Boston, Massachusetts 02115 

RE:	ICE FOIA Case Number 2025-ICFO-53236 
 
Dear Requester: 

This letter is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), dated 8/5/2025.  You have requested Introductory announcement, prepared remarks, agenda items, and other materials related to the appointment of Ricky J. Patel as special agent in charge of the New York Area of Responsibility 

ICE has considered your request under both the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. § 552, and the Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552a.  Information about an individual that is maintained in a Privacy Act system of records may be accessed by that individual unless the agency has exempted the system of records from the access provisions of the Privacy Act. 

ICE has conducted a search of the ICE for records responsive to your request and no records responsive to your request were found. HSI 

For your information, Congress excluded three discrete categories of law enforcement and national security records from the requirements of the FOIA.  See 5 U.S.C. § 552(c) (2006 & Supp. IV (2010).  This response is limited to those records that are subject to the requirements of the FOIA.  This is a standard notification that is given to all our requesters and should not be taken as an indication that excluded records do, or do not, exist. 

While an adequate search was conducted, you have the right to appeal this determination that no records exist within the above mentioned ICE office(s).  Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of the original response letter, within 90 days of the date of the letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8.  You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to: 

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement 
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor 
U.S. Department of Homeland Security 
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900 
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900 

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.”  Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia. 

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees.  In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge. 

If you have any questions please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St., SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009 and refer to your tracking number. Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation.  If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974.  You may contact OGIS as follows:  Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448. 

Sincerely, 

Megan Davis 
Deputy FOIA Officer, Operations

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All proposals related (including price proposals) to the RFP for San Jose's automated enforcement speed zone pilot program (https://www.sanjoseca.gov/your-government/departments-offices/transportation/projects/speed-cameras-project).

As well as the contract with Verra Mobility for related services.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jon Smith

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of January 30, 2026., Reference # R011293-013026. 
Dear Jon Smith, 
The City of San Jose received a public information request from you on January 30, 2026. Your request stated: "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All proposals related (including price proposals) to the RFP for San Jose's automated enforcement speed zone pilot program (https://www.sanjoseca.gov/your-government/departments-offices/transportation/projects/speed-cameras-project). 

As well as the contract with Verra Mobility for related services. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Jon Smith 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2204163/" 
The California Public Records Act requires the City to provide requested records to customers. However, California Government Code § 7922.545 (former Government Code § 6253(f)) states that the requirement is met when the public agency posts “any public record on its internet website and, in response to a request for a public record posted on the internet website, directing a member of the public to the location on the internet website where the public record is posted.” 
The contract with Verra Mobility can be found here. If you experience difficulty with the link, please copy and paste the below into your browser. https://sanjoseca.govnita.com/workspaces/Contracts?query=Verra%20Mobility 
Staff is continuing to search for responsive records for the remainder of your request, and an update will be provided no later than February 11, 2026. 
If you have any questions or need additional information, please reply to this email. 
Sincerely, 
DOT PRA Coordinator 

Department of Transportation

title: VCU - Ed McLaughlin

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: VCU - Ed McLaughlin
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

(1)   Any signed and/or executed employment contract/agreement/offer letter/memorandum of understanding between Virginia Commonwealth University and Ed McLaughlin, and

(2)   Any subsequent signed and/or executed employment contract extension/amendment/offer letter/memorandum of understanding of such, between VCU and Mr. McLaughlin.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Ellen.

title: Family Member Care Tax Credit Statistics

communications.subject: North Dakota Open Records Law Request: Family Member Care Tax Credit Statistics
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Dakota Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Information related to the Family Member Care Tax Credit from as far back as data systems will allow through 2025. Specifically, the following information, as it is available:

1) Number of returns that claimed the credit
2) Total amount of credits claimed ($)
3) If available, (1) and (2) separately by taxpayer characteristics, such as filing status, marital status, age of taxpayer, AGI range, number of dependents, etc.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: Record Request Family Member Care Tax Credit
communications.communication:
Ms. Pepin,

We are in receipt of your record request dated January 24, 2026, which we received today. We are in the process of reviewing your request and will reach out soon.

If you have any questions regarding this request, please feel free to contact me.

Sincerely,

Matthew Danielson
Special Assistant Attorney General
NORTH DAKOTA OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER
600 E Boulevard Ave., Dept. 127
Bismarck, ND 58505-0599

communications.subject: Family Member Care Tax Credit North Dakota
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Pepin:

Although you framed your request as an open records request, what you seem to be seeking is for us to collect statistical data. You requested information regarding the Family Member Care Tax Credit including:


  1.  Number of returns that claimed the credit
  2.  Total amount of credits claimed ($)
  3.  If available, (1) and (2) separately by taxpayer characteristics, such as filing status, marital status, age of taxpayer, AGI range, number of dependents, etc.

Because the purpose of an open records request is to obtain copies of records that already exist, our response to your request as an open records request would be that we have no documents responsive to your request.

However, we were able to collect the data you were seeking. Attached to this email is an Excel document with the information we were able to pull from our system. The credit information is stated by year, amount, and number of claimants, and contains two tables sorting the information by federal AGI and filing status. Please note that the earliest available information is from tax year 2000, and that these totals reflect the actual credit amount claimed on individual income tax returns based on the unique circumstances of each return.

Based on changes in tax law in 2023, which generally eliminated the payment obligation for the lowest bracket of individual income tax (approximately Federal taxable income of $50,000 and below), there are no credit amounts to report for the period of 2023 through present.

If I can be of any further assistance with regard to this request, please reach out to me at mfdanielson@nd.gov<mailto:mfdanielson@nd.gov>.

Sincerely,



Matthew Danielson
Special Assistant Attorney General
NORTH DAKOTA OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER
600 E Boulevard Ave., Dept. 127
Bismarck, ND 58505-0599
P: 701-328-2781  |  Fax: 701-328-3700  |  nd.gov/tax<http://www.nd.gov/tax>

[cid:image001.png@01DC99CC.587764F0]

title: Flock Safety ALPR Audits 2026 Q1 (Niles Police Department Illinois)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Flock Safety ALPR Audits 2026 Q1 (Niles Police Department Illinois)
communications.communication:
RE: Flock Safety ALPR Audits

To the FOIA Officer of Niles Police Department Illinois,

This request is made under the provisions of Illinois Freedom of Information Act. for the following records:

1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.

2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period of June 1, 2025, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.

Please provide the audit data in a structured format such as .csv, .xls, or another machine-readable database filetype.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the case of any applicable fees, it is requested that an estimate of the total charges be provided prior to fulfilling this request. The preferred method of receipt is through electronic delivery.

Your assistance and cooperation in this matter are greatly appreciated. A response within 5 business days, as the statute requires is anticipated.

Best,
David S. (he/him/his), Lucy Parsons Labs

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Brazoria County Sheriff's Office)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Brazoria County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

title: FBI: Belgian hardcore straight edge band Nations on Fire

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI: Belgian hardcore straight edge band Nations on Fire
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all responsive documents mentioning the Belgian straight edge hardcore band "Nation on Fire" which was active as band from 1989 to 1994. Two albums that were shipped from Europe and distributed by mail order and sold in record stores in the early 1990s. The band "Nations on Fire" release hardcore albums that featured album covers that likely generated interest by the bureau. These two albums are 1994's "Death of the Pro-Lifer" and 1991's "Strike the Match", these albums featured imagery related to the debate on abortion and an upside down American flag. Please conduct a search for bureau documents generated in response to these two album covers. 

Here's a snippet about the band from the widely read Maximumrocknroll zine from the 1980s/1990s:

https://www.maximumrocknroll.com/band/nations-on-fire/

Please include all potentially responsive materials, including but not limited to all communications, reports, inquiries, investigations, photographs, audio files, video files, memos, directives, etc. Please include all materials found in other subject files and all materials associated with any potentially-related names and any other known aliases, nicknames, code names, or any other identifying pseudonyms or references utilized by this agency. Please consult the Central Records System and records, the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Data Management System and records, Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) records, Physical Surveillance (FISUR) records, Technical Surveillance (TESUR) records, and all available cross-reference indices, databases, and records, in addition to any other locations containing potentially-responsive materials related to Nations on Fire. 

Please include a search of any records or documents related to the 1980s/1990s social movement colloquially referred to as "Straight Edge" or "sXe" that reference the "Nations on Fire" band. 

According to a blog post read, it is important that I state the following: "As you know, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is required to search the records stored at NARA’s Washington Records Center in Suitland, MD, but still technically under the FBI’s control. For more information see 36 CFR 1250.8" Please also conduct a physical search of records at NARA's Washington Records Center in Suitland, for any records or documents related to the "Nations on Fire" band. 

If the bureau cannot fulfill certain parts of this request or certain portions must be redacted please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt, explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion itself the specific exemption(s) claimed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

Email

198406-96237914@requests.muckrock.com

Phone

Location

United States

# Domestic Address

Address Line 1

MuckRock News, DEPT MR198406

Address Line 2

263 Huntington Ave

City

Boston

State

Massachusetts

Postal

02115

# Agreement to Pay

How you will pay

I am limiting my request to the free two hours of searching and 100 duplicated
pages. I am not willing to pay additional fees.

# Non-Individual FOIA Request

Request Information

To Whom It May Concern: Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby
request the following records: Any and all responsive documents mentioning the
Belgian straight edge hardcore band "Nation on Fire" which was active as band
from 1989 to 1994. Two albums that were shipped from Europe and distributed by
mail order and sold in record stores in the early 1990s. The band "Nations on
Fire" release hardcore albums that featured album covers that likely generated
interest by the bureau. These two albums are 1994's "Death of the Pro-Lifer"
and 1991's "Strike the Match", these albums featured imagery related to the
debate on abortion and an upside down American flag. Please conduct a search
for bureau documents generated in response to these two album covers. Here's a
snippet about the band from the widely read Maximumrocknroll zine from the
1980s/1990s: https://www.maximumrocknroll.com/band/nations-on-fire/ Please
include all potentially responsive materials, including but not limited to all
communications, reports, inquiries, investigations, photographs, audio files,
video files, memos, directives, etc. Please include all materials found in
other subject files and all materials associated with any potentially-related
names and any other known aliases, nicknames, code names, or any other
identifying pseudonyms or references utilized by this agency. Please consult
the Central Records System and records, the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR)
Data Management System and records, Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) records,
Physical Surveillance (FISUR) records, Technical Surveillance (TESUR) records,
and all available cross-reference indices, databases, and records, in addition
to any other locations containing potentially-responsive materials related to
Nations on Fire. Please include a search of any records or documents related
to the 1980s/1990s social movement colloquially referred to as "Straight Edge"
or "sXe" that reference the "Nations on Fire" band. According to a blog post
read, it is important that I state the following: "As you know, the Federal
Bureau of Investigation is required to search the records stored at NARA’s
Washington Records Center in Suitland, MD, but still technically under the
FBI’s control. For more information see 36 CFR 1250.8" Please also conduct a
physical search of records at NARA's Washington Records Center in Suitland,
for any records or documents related to the "Nations on Fire" band. If the
bureau cannot fulfill certain parts of this request or certain portions must
be redacted please provide any reasonable segregable portion of a requested
record after removing or redacting those portions claimed to be exempt,
explain in writing the justification for redacting the record, indicate the
extent of any redactions on the portion of the record which is made available
or published and where technically feasible indicate on the redacted portion
itself the specific exemption(s) claimed. Sincerely, Robert Delaware

**

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

**

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

title: Clark County Court Administrator of the District Court Jury List Request

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Clark County Court Administrator of the District Court Jury List Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to NV Rev Stat § 6.045(5)(c)(1)

The following materials regarding the compilation and composition of the state’s master jury list:

All current policies and procedures regarding how the current master jury list was compiled and how often master jury lists are reviewed and updated. Please name all source lists (driver’s license records, voter registration lists, etc) that were utilized in creating the current master jury list.

All reports, databases, spreadsheets, or equivalent materials regarding the composition of the current master jury list. Please include the total number of individuals on the current master jury list and all relevant demographic data, including but not limited to the race, age and gender of individuals that comprise the current master jury list.

In the event that there are any fees for obtaining or copying these records, please inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. Should the fees exceed $100, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees as I am requesting the information on behalf of a 501(c)(3) nonprofit and the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of how master jury lists are created. This information is not being sought for commercial purposes.
If possible, please provide the requested documents electronically. However, if this is not feasible, please inform me of the available methods for obtaining these records. Further, if you expect a significant delay in responding to this request, please contact me with information concerning when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.
If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption that justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within the timeframe required by the statute.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Elijah Salisbury

title: Changes to usaid.gov (United States Agency for International Development)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Changes to usaid.gov (United States Agency for International Development)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records beginning on noon, January 20, 2025, Eastern Time through midnight, February 2, 2025, Eastern Time regarding modifications to the usaid.gov website . Please include the records of source code modifications, infrastructure or software configuration, directions to staff or contractors on what modifications to make, content management system logs (or similar logs should a content management system be used) and documentation of changes to the DNS and other similar records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

realmaga

communications.subject: Request Acknowledgement by USAID
communications.communication: Dear realmaga realmaga, This letter acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the United States Agency for International Development. The tracking number for your request is F-00527-25. Please use this number when corresponding with this office. At this time, we are in the process of perfecting your request. A perfected request for records reasonably describes such records and is made in accordance with the published rules stating the time, place, fees (if any) and procedures to be followed. This process includes reviewing the request for clarity and fee category determination and related commitment to pay, if applicable. Once your request is perfected, you will be notified of the Government Information Specialist assigned to process your case. If you have questions, please contact us on or by e-mail at (tel:(202) 712-0960) (202) 712-0960 . Please cite the above-referenced number when corresponding with our office. (mailto:foia@usaid.gov) foia@usaid.gov Sincerely, The FOIA Team USAID - Washington DC

communications.subject: Re: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Talking points and other material related to 4/19/2024 press conference
communications.communication:
Dear Tom Nash,

Richmond Redevelopment and Housing Authority (RRHA) acknowledges receipt of your FOIA request, dated January 23, 2026, January 8, 2026, and April 18, 2024 as you stated in your email, received in the FOIA department on January 23, 2026. I am not sure why your previous requests were not seen until today and apologize for the inconvenience that may have been caused. Your request is for talking points, scripts, and notes used to prepare for the press conference held on April 19, 2024.

The link provided did not work for me, however I located the press release and believe you are referring to the "RRHA Addresses Lease Enforcement Cases Due to Non-Payment of Rent" Press Conference held on April 19, 2024 at 10 a.m. Please let me know if I am incorrect.

Upon further review, a response will be provided to you within 5 business days of your initial request date. Day 1 is considered the day after your request is received. The five-day period does not include weekends or holidays.  If it is not practically possible to identify, locate, or provide the records you requested within 5 business days, RRHA may require an additional 7 business days to respond to your request pursuant to Va. Code § 2.2-3704(B)(4).

RRHA reserves the right to charge a reasonable fee for searching, duplicating, and supplying the requested records, but the fee shall not exceed the actual costs incurred. You may request an estimate of the cost in advance of receiving the requested records.  All requests received by RRHA are handled pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, Va. Code § 2.2-3700.

Please let me know if you want to modify your request or if you have any questions. Again, I apologize for this delay and any inconvenience this may have caused.

Sincerely,


[A close up of a sign  Description automatically generated]

iACT – Integrity, Accountability, Customer Focus, Teamwork
Defining who we are and how we do business!



Tonise A. Webb

Associate Lead Counsel and Chief Compliance Officer

title: Report and BWC from Firearm Discharge in Hotel

communications.subject: Minnesota Government Data Practices Act Request: Report and BWC from Firearm Discharge in Hotel
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act, I hereby request the following records:

On January 20, 2026 the Minnesota Star Tribune published an article titled "ICE agent accidentally fires gun into Eagan hotel room." To assist with your search, the article included: "The gunshot occurred Dec. 18, at the Hampton Inn Minneapolis-Eagan, located at 3000 Eagandale Place."

We are seeking additional information on this accidental discharge. Please provide the following records:
1) Police report and related supplements and media (photos/videos)
2) 911 Call Audio related to the incident 
3) BWC for responding officer(s)
4) Any interview transcripts or recordings (if separate from #1. If they are included in #1 then please ignore this line)

Thank you for taking the time to fulfill this request. Please feel free to send any of the above items as they become available, they do not all need to be sent at once.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Alan J. Segal

Hello, thank you for acknowledging that receipt of request #26-234

Due to the newsworthiness of this information and ongoing situation throughout the Twin Cities, I respectfully request that this request be expedited as much as reasonable. Files may be sent as they are located instead of batched in a single folder, and reports may be sent before BWC footage and other information that takes longer to collect and review. Thank you for helping with this request.

Respectfully, 
Alan

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R000275-121625
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: Public Records Request of December 16, 2025, Reference # R000275-121625 Dear Kung Joe, The Bellevue School District Public Records Office received the following public records request from you on December 16, 2025: To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All email exchanged between Bellevue School District and the Washington State School Directors' association (*@wssda.org) for all time. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Kung Fu Joe 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2156999/ In accordance with , we are acknowledging receipt of your request and providing notice that the District will require additional time to respond. This time is needed to seek any clarifications to the request and to locate, assemble, and review the requested records.  RCW 42.56.520 Please note that this request may be subject to applicable fees as permitted by the PRA. RCW 42.56.120. The District charges 5 cents for 4 electronic files/or attachments. RCW 42.56.120(2)(b)(iii). We will let you know in advance if there will be a fee and whether, in keeping with RCW 42.56.120(4), a 10% fee deposit will be required before we proceed with your request. Please be aware that, in keeping with our obligations under the Washington Public Records Act (PRA), any information that personally identifies a student (unless the requestor is that student’s parent or guardian) must be redacted from all materials provided in response to a public records request. RCW 42.56.230(1). We ran some preliminary searches to get a sense for the number of potentially responsive emails. A search for emails from/to/cc @wssda.org returned only 8 emails, which have been uploaded here: Public Records Request - R000275-121625  A search for messages from/to/cc “wssda” returned 111,302 messages, many of which were mass mailings relating to news updates. When we ran a search omitting the most common of those bulk messages (using the search terms below), we had 29,840 messages. The applicable fee for that number of messages would be over $350 – and it seems possible that a large number of those emails might not be of interest to you. We ran that same search just for the period from 12/1/25 to 12/16/25 and had 31 results. We have attached those messages so you can take a look at the types of records the search is pulling up. If you have additional search terms you would like us to use or a specific date range that you would like us to pull first, please let us know. We want to make sure you get what you are interested in without unnecessary expense and without having to slog through records that are of no interest to you. Once we have your direction for a revised search, or your go-ahead to continue with the 29,840-result search, we will provide you with an anticipated fulfillment date and a fee estimate. Please let us know if you have any questions. Sincerely, Sarah Kolpacoff 
Public Records Officer

title: Military equipment (Brownsville Police Department)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Military equipment (Brownsville Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

An inventory of all military equipment held by the department as of the date of fulfillment of this request. The request includes but is not limited to: 

(1) Unmanned, remotely piloted, powered aerial or ground vehicles.
(2) Mine-resistant ambush-protected (MRAP) vehicles or armored personnel carriers. However, police versions of standard consumer vehicles are specifically excluded from this subdivision.
(3) High mobility multipurpose wheeled vehicles (HMMWV), commonly referred to as Humvees, two and one-half-ton trucks, five-ton trucks, or wheeled vehicles that have a breaching or entry apparatus attached. However, unarmored all-terrain vehicles (ATVs) and motorized dirt bikes are specifically excluded from this subdivision.
(4) Tracked armored vehicles that provide ballistic protection to their occupants and utilize a tracked system instead of wheels for forward motion.
(5) Command and control vehicles that are either built or modified to facilitate the operational control and direction of public safety units.
(6) Weaponized aircraft, vessels, or vehicles of any kind.
(7) Battering rams, slugs, and breaching apparatuses that are explosive in nature. However, items designed to remove a lock, such as bolt cutters, or a handheld ram designed to be operated by one person, are specifically excluded from this subdivision.
(8) Firearms of .50 caliber or greater.
(9) Ammunition of .50 caliber or greater.
(10) Specialized firearms and ammunition of less than .50 caliber, including assault weapons as defined in Sections 30510 and 30515 of the Penal Code.
(11) Any firearm or firearm accessory that is designed to launch explosive projectiles.
(12) “Flashbang” grenades and explosive breaching tools, “tear gas,” and “pepper balls,” excluding standard, service-issued handheld pepper spray.
(13) Taser Shockwave, microwave weapons, water cannons, and the Long Range Acoustic Device (LRAD).
(14) The following projectile launch platforms and their associated munitions: 40mm projectile launchers, “bean bag,” rubber bullet, and specialty impact munition (SIM) weapons.
(15) Any other military equipment purchased by/for or transferred to the department. 

Requested components of the inventory:
The inventory should include the manufacturer, model number, quantity, initial costs of obtaining the equipment, and estimated annual costs of maintaining the equipment of each type of equipment, where "type" means each item shares the same manufacturer model number. 

The inventory should also specify under which program the equipment was obtained if applicable, including but not limited to the 1033 Program, the 1122 Program, the US Department of Homeland Security Grant Program, US Department of Justice’s Justice Assistant Grant Program, DOJ Equitable Sharing Program, US Department of the Treasury Forfeiture Fund’s Equitable Sharing Program, and The General Services Administration Federal Surplus Personal Property Donation program.  

I am also requesting a list of all military inventory that has gone missing in 2024 and 2025. 

I am a journalist employed by the news outlet The American Prospect and I am requesting a waiver of all fees. The disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of the tools available to the department to maintain safety and order, and protect against attacks from both domestic and outside sources.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Whitney Wimbish

title: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Seminole County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Sheriff use of force data (2017-2025) (Seminole County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Use of force (UOF) data dating from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2025. If possible, please provide this data in database or spreadsheet format and include the case number, incident date, incident time, subject injured indicator, subject injury force related info (e.g. Yes or No), subject age, subject gender, subject ethnicity, subject weapon type, incident area occurred, force type, officer division (e.g. law enforcement operations, detention/correctional operations, etc.), badge number and names associated with the officers involved. If one or more of these fields or dates is unavailable, provide all fields and/or information that is available responsive to my request. If no database or spreadsheet format is available, please provide copies of each individual use of force report or other report where use of force information is documented/reported by officers. Note, this is for all use of force incidents reported by your agency, not limited to only those incidents required to be reported under state or federal programs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Samuel Sinyangwe

Memorandum_Regarding_Potential_Impeachment_Information_Deputy_Ryan_Taylor.pdf (https://u8387778.ct.sendgrid.net/ls/click?upn=u001.VEsWrlMiJDg0mXafq1mEXXKNHMGZjOd7qdQtHPrqDUSnThnOAjge8ztdyL9xIcfHcJ-2FbxPyhrYsO296qCMQ4ksLV0AeLB8FTdVj2TxPKIoOejmO9Hu5hjYGNuUgEsV3twh-2FGX8ct09m2q9036luX2U6JTVmSqInv5z5Jxubx0yS4NikHNONKe6JzJ-2FcFTPgf-2BK0TP4wY-2Bz22TO42gSbnbA-3D-3D9QSd_lhUZe-2BLXd-2BneSB-2BTZtjOVt2wFbPVps7QJsV-2B-2BSlReCUL0O0E4T5MYMxN5XaLaf5Bc5a2A60REPfDoCov-2BuA5kBIe2ZwemQDT8wzbzEM9hc5uwurAGiFw1vjpKX8NQBdwkLnaC-2B1Y0vCgyGg6Pp4GbeL6a4is4WgXvLQ3CT4WPu1YjpYQfsYqgl4is6zz4DG42UaSupiRWX5oS2WfWt7ujzF3JJEK81-2FkLDekrSI7R1wusz2ik5vnTim1Q-2BQNfOg2OXJI-2Bux5HkWCi065Y-2FvMaqouE0Amm4T3KavEamQ4MSQXnfT-2FVMUPb6EyC7-2Ff6GjXsB4MaZYclE44DRAT9m9uzOsnQsjD9OSPV-2BqfnAyGP29QKYLZssoec-2FF2jyt8iMyNISLmvVrrg5NN-2BCWOO2BP7A-3D-3D) 

--- Please respond above this line --- 
RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of February 03, 2026, Reference #C003886-020326 Dear Ms. Terse: Greetings. My name is Joseph Anderson and I am a Deputy Public Records Officer for Skamania County. I assist inreviewing and responding to public records requests (PRRs) for alldepartments. 

On February 03, 2026, I received your public records request as follows: "To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office, along with accompanying potential impeachment material. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Rose Terse 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2208085/." 
Please note that Skamania County does not have a ' Brady List' per se.  There is one (1) deputy that worksfor the Skamania County Sheriff’s Office for whom we have potentialimpeachment information and for whom we provide a memo disclosing and summarizing thecircumstances. We provide this memo when required to defense counsel oncases involving this deputy. Because there is only one (1) local deputy forwhom we maintain potential impeachment disclosure information, there is no list. Just the singlememo, which we are happy to provide [ please see attached]. 

TheWashington State Patrol sometimes sends us information from state-widepotential impeachment issues with WSP employees. We do not maintain thisinformation in any organized way because it does not apply to anyofficers that regularly appear in our courts/cases. I just want toconfirm that these records are not made into any list, and to the extentthat these records are related to WSP employees, are likely bettersought from the WSP directly, if you’re interested in the raw data (inaddition to any lists). After reviewing our files, we have located records that are responsive to your request. Please log in to the Skamania County Public Records Center at the following link to retrieve the records responsive to your request: County Public Records Request - C003886-020326
SkamaniaCounty has searched for, attempted to identify, locate, and provide anynon-exempt public records that may be responsive to this request. Since this completely fulfills your request, we are now closing this public records request. The one (1) yearstatute of limitations to seek judicial review under the Public RecordsAct (Chapter 42.56 RCW) begins now because Skamania County does notintend to further address this request. Please feel free to contact me if you have any further questions or concerns by replying to this email or at my phone number below. 

Sincerely, 

Joseph Anderson 
Deputy Public Records Officer 
Office of the Skamania County Prosecuting Attorney 
240 NW Vancouver Avenue | PO Box 790 
Stevenson, WA 98648 
509-427-3791
